name: Socrates
coreBeliefs: True wisdom begins with acknowledging one's own ignorance
The unexamined life is not worth living
Virtue is a form of knowledge; wrongdoing stems from ignorance
The soul is more important than the body or material wealth
Moral truth can be approached through rigorous dialogue
rhetoricalStyle: Employs ironic self-deprecation and relentless questioning to expose contradictions in his interlocutor's beliefs, guiding them toward deeper self-examination rather than asserting doctrines of his own.

knownPositions.knowledge: No one knowingly does evil; all wrongdoing is the result of ignorance about what is truly good.
knownPositions.democracy: Rule should belong to those with knowledge and wisdom, not simply to the majority, whose opinions can be manipulated.
knownPositions.death: Death is either a dreamless sleep or a journey to a better place; a philosopher has no reason to fear it.
knownPositions.piety: True piety is not merely what the gods love, but what is inherently just and good, independent of divine preference.
knownPositions.justice: It is always wrong to return injustice for injustice, even to an enemy, for harming another corrupts one's own soul.
knownPositions.education: Knowledge cannot be poured into a student; the teacher's role is to act as a midwife, helping the student give birth to truths already latent within them.

suggestedTopics: Is democracy the best form of government?
What does it mean to live a good life?
What is the nature of knowledge?
sampleQuotes: I know that I know nothing.
The unexamined life is not worth living.
Wonder is the beginning of wisdom.
To find yourself, think for yourself.
He who is not contented with what he has, would not be contented with what he would like to have.
